Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: F: DKA: CSD: Topological Data Analysis and Machine-Learning with Community-Accepted Features

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a new set of techniques from topological data analysis (TDA) to enrich the analytical toolkit for big data problems. In particular, TDA is well-suited at picking up repetitive (even quasi-repetitive) patterns that exist at many different scale levels within a dataset. The developed techniques can be applied to many multimedia applications. For example, a system that can correctly recognize certain motion patterns from a large set of surveillance data can help to identify threatening situations as they arise. Or a methodology that takes short song snippets and extract indicators of genre similarity may eventually be used to suggest new sound patterns.

This project constructs an analytical pipeline for using TDA-ML (machine-learning) methods on features already in use in the multimedia research communities. Topological Data Analysis (TDA) is almost fifteen years old. One of its key tools is the persistence diagram (PD), a compact and robust summary of the low-dimensional multi-scale topological and geometric information in a high-dimensional point cloud. Crucially, this information is extracted without need for dimension reduction. Over the last few years, two exciting developments have enriched TDA. First, theoretical and practical work on algorithms and implementations has enabled the fast computation of large numbers of PDs. Second, a coherent methodology has developed to do machine-learning (ML) with PDs as features, with several examples showing that one can augment more-standard feature sets with PD features, and find interesting signal that was not apparent before. This research discovers compelling signals in these features which are not previously apparent, but are immediately understandable because of the choice of features. The research team investigates both video and audio features. The ML methods are used to further measure importance of the features in a given context.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on combining methods from mathematics (Topological Data Analysis - TDA) with machine learning to find new insights into video, music and other types of time-varying data streams. The approach was to develop "shape-descriptors" for each modality of data - e.g. repeating, overlayed patterns in music, characteristic features of vehicle operation in tracking and navigation, etc. The shape descriptors are then used to define features for each modality. Self-similarity is the main approach, where the team has a wide variety of ways to measure how similar the data is at different times. For example, if one is monitoring a vehicle, self-similarity using radar gives a patterns that can indicate when the vehicle is turning (and which direction), accelerating, etc. For tracking this gives a behavioral description that can be used to resolve confusion (Is that the car I was tracking earlier before it went behind the building?).

During the duration of this project there was a significant evolution in machine learning. Deep learning (DL) was already established, but it grew exponentially. A major point of DL is that if one has enough data, one doesn't have to find important features in advance. However, it still remains clear that in data sparse situations, or situations where there is lots of data but it isn't labeled, DL struggles. The methods developed in this project help bridge this gap as one can do learning in the features space given the TDA methods and get much better results.

Work in the project has spun off to a small company, Geometric Data Analytics (GDA), started in 2012 by the PI and co-PI. GDA has software engineers that are using the methods from this and other projects of the PI and co-PI to develop software solutions to a wide variety of problems. The company has done most of its work for the DoD so far, but is now expanding its efforts into the private sector.
